question.text: Many people believe that countries should produce food for all the population and import as little as possible. To what extent do you agree or disagree?

questionType.explanation: You must take a clear position on whether countries should aim for food self-sufficiency. You can fully agree, partly agree, or disagree.
requirements: State your position clearly in the introduction
Provide 2-3 main arguments supporting your position
Acknowledge the opposing view briefly if taking a balanced position

keyWords.importance: The main action - focus on domestic agricultural production

keyWords.definition: Sufficient food to feed the entire country
Minimize buying food from other countries
keyWords.importance: The opposite of food imports and trade dependency
Signals you can agree, partially agree, or disagree

essayStructure.body1: 4-5 sentences: First main argument with explanation and example
essayStructure.body2: 4-5 sentences: Second main argument with explanation and example

commonMistakes: Not taking a clear position on the issue

steps.title: Build Paragraphs
steps.completionCriteria: Complete all 4 paragraphs (10+ words per blank)

content.instructions: Fill in each blank to build your essay paragraph by paragraph. Aim for 10-15 words per blank.

paragraphs.name: Introduction
paragraphs.template: The debate over _____ [introduce the topic] has gained prominence in recent years. While _____ [acknowledge opposing view], I believe _____ [clearly state YOUR position].

blanks.label: Introduce the topic
blanks.hint: Start with 'food self-sufficiency' or 'whether countries should produce all their food'
blanks.placeholder: e.g., whether countries should strive for complete food self-sufficiency rather than relying on imports

blanks.label: Acknowledge opposing view
blanks.hint: Briefly mention the case for self-sufficiency
blanks.placeholder: e.g., food security is undeniably important for national stability and independence

blanks.label: Your position
blanks.hint: Be clear! State if you agree, disagree, or partly agree
blanks.placeholder: e.g., complete agricultural self-sufficiency is unrealistic and economically inefficient for most nations

paragraphs.name: Body Paragraph 1
paragraphs.template: Firstly, _____ [topic sentence - your first main argument]. This is because _____ [explain the reason]. For instance, _____ [give a specific example]. As a result, _____ [state the consequence].

blanks.label: Topic sentence - first argument
blanks.hint: Main reason why self-sufficiency is difficult/impossible
blanks.placeholder: e.g., geographical and climate limitations make complete food self-sufficiency impossible for many countries

blanks.label: Explain the reason
blanks.placeholder: e.g., different crops require specific climate conditions and soil types that are not available everywhere

blanks.label: Specific example
blanks.placeholder: e.g., Japan imports over sixty percent of its food because it lacks sufficient agricultural land to feed its dense population

blanks.label: Consequence
blanks.hint: What is the outcome of trying to be self-sufficient despite limitations?
blanks.placeholder: e.g., forcing complete self-sufficiency would lead to severe food shortages and dramatically increased food prices

paragraphs.name: Body Paragraph 2
paragraphs.template: Moreover, _____ [topic sentence - second argument]. The reason is _____ [explain why]. For example, _____ [specific example]. Therefore, _____ [conclusion about this argument].

blanks.label: Topic sentence - second argument
blanks.hint: Economic benefits of trade or specialization
blanks.placeholder: e.g., international trade allows countries to specialize in products they can produce efficiently

blanks.label: Explain why
blanks.placeholder: e.g., countries can focus resources on their agricultural strengths while importing products others produce more efficiently

blanks.label: Specific example
blanks.hint: Concrete example of successful agricultural trade
blanks.placeholder: e.g., New Zealand exports dairy products worldwide while importing tropical fruits and grains it cannot grow competitively

blanks.label: Conclusion about this argument
blanks.hint: What does this demonstrate about food trade?
blanks.placeholder: e.g., this specialization reduces costs and provides consumers with diverse food options at reasonable prices

paragraphs.name: Conclusion
paragraphs.template: In conclusion, while _____ [acknowledge the opposing concern], I believe _____ [restate your position with final thought].

blanks.label: Acknowledge opposing concern
blanks.placeholder: e.g., maintaining some domestic food production capacity is important for national security

blanks.label: Restate position + final thought
blanks.hint: Clearly restate YOUR position and add recommendation
blanks.placeholder: e.g., complete self-sufficiency is impractical and countries should pursue strategic food security through balanced trade and targeted domestic production

content.instructions: Now combine your paragraphs into a complete essay. Aim for 250-280 words total.

Body paragraph 1 explains geographical/climate limitations with example

modelEssay.text:
The question of whether countries should strive for complete food self-sufficiency has become increasingly debated in an era of globalization. While food security is undeniably important for national stability, I believe that complete agricultural self-sufficiency is unrealistic and economically inefficient for most nations.

Firstly, geographical and climate limitations make complete food self-sufficiency impossible for many countries. Different crops require specific temperature ranges, rainfall patterns, and soil conditions that simply do not exist everywhere. For instance, Japan imports over sixty percent of its food because its mountainous terrain and limited arable land cannot support sufficient agricultural production to feed its dense population of 125 million people. Similarly, Singapore imports nearly ninety percent of its food due to severe land constraints. As a result, forcing complete self-sufficiency in such nations would lead to severe food shortages and dramatically increased food prices that would harm consumers.

Moreover, international food trade allows countries to benefit from comparative advantage and economic efficiency. When nations specialize in producing foods they can grow efficiently while importing products that others produce better, overall costs decrease and quality improves. For example, New Zealand exports dairy products and lamb worldwide while importing tropical fruits, coffee, and grains it cannot produce competitively. The United Kingdom faced this reality after Brexit, as domestic production could not replace the diverse food imports from Europe without substantial price increases. Therefore, strategic food trade enables countries to provide citizens with affordable, diverse diets while supporting their agricultural sectors in areas where they excel.

In conclusion, while maintaining some domestic food production capacity is important for emergency preparedness, I believe complete self-sufficiency is impractical for most countries. A balanced approach combining strategic domestic production with international trade agreements provides better food security and economic outcomes.
